description: From Middle English tesel, tasil, tasel, tosel, from Old English tǣsel, tǣsl, from Proto-West Germanic *taisilu.

entries.meaning: Any of several plants of the genus Dipsacus.
The dried flower head of the fuller's teasel, Dipsacus fullonum, used for teasing or carding cloth.
Any contrivance intended as a substitute for teasels in dressing cloth.

verbs.description: teasel (third-person singular simple present teasels, present participle teaselling or teaseling, simple past and past participle teaselled or teaseled)

entries.meaning: (archaic) To raise the nap on cloth; to tease; to card.
